title: Gareth Bowen
text:
Gareth Bowen (born 20 June 1979) is a Welsh former <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer who played as a <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Fly-half">fly-half</a>. Born in <a href="Aberdare">Aberdare</a>, he played for <a href="Bridgend%20Ravens">Bridgend</a>, <a href="Bedford%20Blues">Bedford</a>, <a href="Bristol%20Bears">Bristol</a>, <a href="Llanelli%20RFC">Llanelli</a>, <a href="Scarlets">Scarlets</a>, <a href="Neath%20RFC">Neath</a>, <a href="Stade%20Aurillacois%20Cantal%20Auvergne">Aurillac</a>, <a href="Ebbw%20Vale%20RFC">Ebbw Vale</a> and <a href="Newport%20RFC">Newport</a>.
Career.
After spending time with <a href="Bridgend%20Ravens">Bridgend</a> and in England with <a href="Bedford%20Blues">Bedford</a> and <a href="Bristol%20Bears">Bristol</a>, <a href="Wales%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales under-21</a> international Bowen joined Llanelli for the inaugural season of the <a href="Pro14">Celtic League</a> in 2001 and shared duties at fly-half with <a href="Stephen%20Jones%20%28rugby%20union%29">Stephen Jones</a>. His performances earned him a call-up to both the <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">Wales Sevens</a> and <a href="Wales%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales 'A' teams</a> in October 2001, although in February 2002, he had to fly home from Sevens duty in New Zealand to cover for Jones who had been ordered to miss a game against <a href="Ebbw%20Vale%20RFC">Ebbw Vale</a> to guard him against injury ahead of the <a href="2002%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2002 Six Nations</a>.
In 2003, regional rugby came to Wales and Bowen and Jones were named as the two fly-halves for the Llanelli-based region, the <a href="Scarlets">Llanelli Scarlets</a>; however, the start of the 2003–04 season coincided with the <a href="2003%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2003 Rugby World Cup</a> in Australia, which meant Jones was unavailable and Bowen started at fly-half for the first 10 games in the history of the Scarlets. Jones returned from the World Cup as first-choice, but the <a href="2004%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2004 Six Nations Championship</a> meant Bowen had another run in the team before the end of the season and he signed a new contract with the Scarlets in April 2004. Jones left for French side <a href="ASM%20Clermont%20Auvergne">Clermont</a> in the summer of 2004, and failed moves for New Zealander <a href="Andrew%20Mehrtens">Andrew Mehrtens</a> and France's <a href="G%C3%A9rald%20Merceron">Gérald Merceron</a> meant Bowen was now considered the Scarlets' first-choice fly-half, although the newly signed <a href="Arwel%20Thomas">Arwel Thomas</a> and the young <a href="Ceiron%20Thomas">Ceiron Thomas</a> challenged him for the starting position at various points in the 2004–05 season.
In 2005–06, the Scarlets signed <a href="United%20States%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">United States</a> international <a href="Mike%20Hercus">Mike Hercus</a> as competition for Bowen, limiting Bowen to just 10 starts during the season, although in October 2005, he was included as part of Wales' training squad for the <a href="2005%20end-of-year%20rugby%20union%20internationals">2005 Autumn internationals</a>. The return of Stephen Jones to the Scarlets and the emergence of Ceiron Thomas saw Bowen omitted from the Scarlets' 38-man squad for the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Heineken%20Cup">2006–07 Heineken Cup</a>; his only appearance for the region in 2006–07 came as a replacement in a pre-season friendly against <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester</a> in August 2006, and he was limited to eight competitive appearances for Llanelli RFC before his contract was terminated in November 2006. Despite interest from <a href="Leeds%20Tykes">Leeds Tykes</a>, he was almost immediately signed by Neath, who were seeking a replacement at fly-half for <a href="James%20Hook%20%28rugby%20union%29">James Hook</a>, who had been promoted to the <a href="Ospreys%20%28rugby%20union%29">Ospreys</a> regional side.
Bowen left Wales for France in the summer of 2007, signing for <a href="Rugby%20Pro%20D2">second-division</a> side <a href="Stade%20Aurillacois%20Cantal%20Auvergne">Aurillac</a> but returned to sign for his first club, Bridgend, in July 2008. A year later, he moved to Ebbw Vale before joining <a href="Newport%20RFC">Newport</a> in 2010, where he spent two years before retiring.
